project_metadata.paper_title: Creating large, high-quality geospatial datasets from historical maps using novice volunteers
project_metadata.research_context: Crowdsourced digitization of archaeological features from historical maps using mobile GIS platform (FAIMS Mobile) deployed during field archaeology project in Bulgaria

timeline.prior_work: 2008-2016 TRAP catalogued 773 mounds in Kazanlak Valley and 431 mounds in Yambol region using pedestrian surface survey

location.broader_project: Tundzha Regional Archaeological Project (TRAP) - middle and upper Tundzha River watershed in Bulgaria since 2008

resources.equipment: mobile devices (only 2 of 12 students brought computers, all had mobile devices)
resources.software: FAIMS Mobile platform (open-source, customizable Android application)

track_record.prior_FAIMS_use: previously used for student-led ceramics recording project and improved recording efficiency in other settings

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile was used to digitise 10,827 mound features from Soviet military topographic maps during 2017-2018
evidence.verbatim_quote: Deployed in Bulgaria as an ancillary activity during 2017–2018 archaeological fieldwork, FAIMS Mobile was used to digitise 10,827 mound features from Soviet military topographic maps.

evidence.evidence_text: Digitisation required 241 person-hours total (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers)
evidence.verbatim_quote: This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.

evidence.evidence_text: Error rate under 6%
evidence.verbatim_quote: This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.

evidence.evidence_text: Resulting dataset was ready for analysis with a few hours of processing
evidence.verbatim_quote: The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing.

evidence.evidence_text: TRAP catalogued 773 mounds in Kazanlak Valley and 431 mounds in Yambol region between 2008 and 2016
evidence.verbatim_quote: Between 2008 and 2016, TRAP catalogued some 773 mounds in the Kazanlak Valley and 431 mounds in the Yambol region using pedestrian surface survey supported by manual digitisation of satellite imagery and maps.
evidence.extraction_notes: Project context/track record - moved to project_metadata. Keeping here as it establishes scale of prior work.

evidence.evidence_text: An estimated 50,000 burial mounds were built in Bulgarian lands from Early Bronze Age through Middle Ages
evidence.verbatim_quote: An estimated 50,000 burial mounds were built in Bulgarian lands from the Early Bronze Age through the Middle Ages (Shkorpil & Shkorpil, 1989, p. 20; Kitov, 1993, p. 42).

evidence.evidence_text: Mounds range in size from 10 to 50 m in diameter and 0.5–20 m in height
evidence.verbatim_quote: They were constructed of earth and rubble, and range in size from 10 to 50 m in diameter and 0.5–20 m in height (see Fig. 1).

evidence.evidence_text: Mounds are at risk of looting, destroyed in development (sometimes with rescue excavations), and degraded by agricultural activities
evidence.verbatim_quote: Because they may contain intrinsically valuable grave goods, mounds are at risk of looting (Loulanski & Loulanski, 2017). Others are destroyed in the course of development, sometimes preceded by rescue excavations (Cholakov & Chukalev, 2008). Still others are degraded by agricultural activities, particularly as pasturelands are repurposed to arable farming (Eftimoski et al., 2017).

evidence.evidence_text: Manual digitisation using desktop GIS is time-consuming and requires specialised skills
evidence.verbatim_quote: Manually drawing and annotating shapes in historical maps using a desktop GIS is time-consuming and requires specialised skills (Can, Gerrits, and Kabadayi 2021; Petrie et al., 2018; Jones & Weber, 2012).

evidence.evidence_text: Desktop GIS manual digitisation has principal limitations of difficulty scaling, restricted expert time, and training burden for novices
evidence.verbatim_quote: Its principal limitations are difficulty of scaling the effort, particularly restricted time and availability of expert users to either undertake digitisation themselves, or to train and support novices to the extent required for efficient and accurate work (see also Jessop, 2007 for other challenges).

evidence.evidence_text: ML requires specific programming expertise, familiarity with ML capabilities/limitations, and can produce biased/unreliable results with naive use
evidence.verbatim_quote: ML has unmatched potential for large-scale data digitisation, but it requires specific programming expertise, and familiarity with the capabilities and limitations of ML. Naive use of ML is likely to produce biased or otherwise unreliable results (Mehrabi et al., 2021; Schwemmer et al., 2020; Besse et al., 2018; Fuchs, 2018; Haas, 2017), even if pretrained image recognition models are used (Jiang et al., 2022).

evidence.evidence_text: ML technical expertise is in high demand and difficult to attract to smaller HASS projects
evidence.verbatim_quote: This technical expertise is in high demand, and may be difficult to attract to the smaller humanities and social sciences (HASS) projects that undertake much of this digitisation.

evidence.evidence_text: ML training requires manual creation and preparation of training data and manual quality assurance
evidence.verbatim_quote: Training an algorithm, moreover, requires manual creation and preparation of training data and manual quality assurance (Bennett et al., 2014; Can & Kabadayi, 2021).

evidence.evidence_text: Volunteers often lack skills necessary to use GIS software
evidence.verbatim_quote: Volunteers often lack the skills necessary to use GIS software (Elwood, 2008b; Jones & Weber, 2012; Owen et al., 2009).

evidence.evidence_text: Novice volunteer experience often limited to 'dropping pins' on web slippy-maps like Google Maps
evidence.verbatim_quote: Often, their experience is limited to 'dropping pins' on web 'slippy-maps' like Google Maps.

evidence.evidence_text: Expert training/guidance can bridge digital divide but scales poorly due to restricted expert time and volunteer willingness limits
evidence.verbatim_quote: This 'digital divide' can be bridged in part through more expert training and guidance of novice users (Owen et al., 2009, p. 24). Such an approach scales poorly, however; the supply of expert time available to any project is restricted and often oversubscribed, while the willingness of volunteers to learn specialised skills and software has limits.

evidence.evidence_text: Soviet topographic maps from 1980s at 1:50,000 scale, each covering ca 400 sq km, contained symbols averaging 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), ranging 50-400 per tile
evidence.verbatim_quote: Available as georeferenced GeoTIFFs (from http://web.uni-plovdiv.bg/vedrin/index_en.html in 2008), each of these maps covers ca 400 sq km. We wished to extract symbols from them that might represent burial or settlement mounds in our study area (see Fig. 2). Such symbols occurred at a high density, averaging about 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), with counts per tile ranging from about 50 to 400.

evidence.evidence_text: Maps of Yambol region contained 1,000+ targeted symbols
evidence.verbatim_quote: We knew that the maps of the Yambol region contained 1,000+ of these targeted symbols.

evidence.evidence_text: Students came from range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities, most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods
evidence.verbatim_quote: Our students came from a range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities. Most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods (unlike Pődör, 2015 or Can et al., 2021).

evidence.evidence_text: In 2010 volunteer approach with ArcGIS was unsuccessful - novices found desktop GIS challenging, many quit, those continuing required ongoing support, volunteer attrition + staff demands rendered approach unsuccessful
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2010, project staff worked with student volunteers to digitise map features using ArcGIS. Our experience was much like that of other projects: novice volunteers found learning to configure and navigate desktop GIS challenging; many quit and those who continued required ongoing support. In the end, volunteer attrition combined with demands on staff time during the height of fieldwork rendered this approach unsuccessful.

evidence.evidence_text: 2017 field season was short with little time for student training
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2017, faced with a short field season and little time for student training, we focused on implementing tools that would empower volunteers to digitise maps independently.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS Mobile worked offline, met functional requirements for geospatial software, allowed testing of usability approaches from kinetic fieldwork
evidence.verbatim_quote: First, FAIMS Mobile worked offline. Our digitisation took place alongside fieldwork, at field bases in rural Bulgaria. Reliable internet connectivity could not be guaranteed under these circumstances; a system that tolerated degraded network connectivity was required. In our experience, digitisation work associated with archaeological research often proceeds under such conditions. Second, this system met the functional requirements we identified for geospatial software.

evidence.evidence_text: Only 2 of 12 students brought computers but all had mobile devices
evidence.verbatim_quote: This choice also reduced competition for the limited number of computers, ESRI licences, and desk space available in the field, plus it allowed students to use their own devices (only two of 12 students brought computers, and none brought mice, but all had mobile devices).

evidence.evidence_text: 2017: customisation required 35h from student programmer + 4h from staff
evidence.verbatim_quote: For the first season of use (2017), creating the Map Digitisation customisation of FAIMS Mobile required 35 h from an undergraduate student programmer plus 4 h from staff (Nassif-Haynes et al., 2021).

evidence.evidence_text: 2017: Setup/configuration in field required 3h staff; map preparation 1.5h; file compression/transfer 2.5h; training/supervision 0.5h total across season
evidence.verbatim_quote: Setup of the server and configuration of the client devices in the field required 3 h from staff. Map preparation (tiling, adding pyramids) required about 1.5 h. Monitoring file compression, upload to the server, and download to devices took an additional 2.5 h. Training and supervision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire season.

evidence.evidence_text: 2017: 125.8 person-hours concentrated across 5 rainy days; 8,343 features digitised from 42 maps (ca 17,000 sq km); average 54s per record
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2017, it was used for a total of 125.8 person-hours concentrated across five rainy days, during which time 8,343 features were digitised from 42 Soviet topographic maps (ca. 17,000 sq km). The average time to record a point feature was 54 s, based on start and end times of feature creation as recorded by the devices (representing work time excluding pauses between records).

evidence.evidence_text: 2018: 63.6 person-hours; 2,484 features from 16 maps (ca 6,500 sq km); average 92s per record
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2018, use was more sporadic; participants who stayed at the base for any reason sometimes undertook digitisation. The system was used for 63.6 person-hours, with 2,484 features recorded from 16 maps (ca. 6,500 sq km), an average rate of one record every 92 s.

evidence.evidence_text: Total: 10,827 features in 189.4 student-hours (63s per record); 58 map tiles, 23,500 sq km
evidence.verbatim_quote: In total, 10,827 point features, mostly burial and settlement mounds, were recorded in 189.4 student-hours (63 s per record). Fifty-eight map tiles representing about 23,500 sq km were digitised.

evidence.evidence_text: 2010 desktop GIS effort: 915 features, required 5-7h staff training/support/checking over 3 weeks; most volunteers didn't persevere; one persistent student did almost all work
evidence.verbatim_quote: As noted above, TRAP had attempted an unsatisfactory digitisation effort in 2010 by students using ArcGIS. Although we did not maintain detailed volunteer time-on-task records, we know this effort produced a dataset of 915 features and required about 5–7 h of staff training, support, and error-checking over a three-week period (based on our field journals). The need for high-touch training and support by project staff during fieldwork, combined with a dislike for the activity on the part of students, prevented us from scaling up the use of desktop GIS for volunteer digitisation further, despite attempting to do so. Most volunteers did not persevere with the activity long enough to repay their initial training time. Indeed, one persistent student accounted for almost all the digitised features; without his perseverance, the digitisation effort would have failed entirely.

evidence.evidence_text: Recoverable data omissions: 223 total (2.06%): 205 spatial, 18 attribute; mostly 2017 (192 spatial, 17 attribute = 2.3%); 2018 only 13 spatial, 1 attribute (0.52%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Recoverable data omissions across both years totaled 223 (2.06% of records), including 205 spatial and 18 attribute omissions. Most occurred in 2017 when 192 records (2.3%) had empty latitude and longitude fields and 17 (0.2%) were missing specification of the map symbol. Spatial data omissions resulted from a failure of the software to populate the latitude and longitude fields from the application's SpatiaLite geodatabase due to users moving through the forms too quickly (see 'Application performance' above). Before the 2018 season, we added validation addressing this problem, resulting in only 13 spatial errors and one attribute omission (0.52%).

evidence.evidence_text: Quality assurance check: 4 randomly selected maps (7% of total); 49 errors from 834 true features = 5.87% error rate; breakdown: 42 false negatives, 6 double-marked, 1 classification error, 0 false positives
evidence.verbatim_quote: Second, a review by project staff of four randomly selected maps (7% of the total) found 49 errors from a true count of 834 features, a 5.87% error rate (see Table 3). Forty-two of these errors were false negatives (symbols missed by students). Six were double-marked (Student C digitised a section of a map twice). Students made only one classification error (a similar symbol mistaken for a benchmark), and no outright false positives.

evidence.evidence_text: Staff could directly digitise 60-75 features per staff-hour using desktop GIS
evidence.verbatim_quote: After brief workspace setup, project staff with desktop GIS experience could digitise at a sustained rate of 60–75 features per staff-hour.

evidence.evidence_text: 57h of staff time for crowdsourcing could have produced 3,420-4,275 features if staff digitised directly
evidence.verbatim_quote: At this rate, the 57 h of staff time devoted to set-up, support, and quality assurance for our crowdsourcing system could have resulted in some 3,420–4,275 staff-digitised features (see Table 4).

evidence.evidence_text: With desktop GIS volunteers, 2010 rate was 130-180 features per staff-hour; 57h might produce 7,410-10,260 features at highest rate, almost competitive with mobile approach
evidence.verbatim_quote: Had specialist project staff instead trained and supervised volunteers to use desktop GIS for digitisation, based on our 2010 digitisation rate of 130–180 features per staff-hour, 57 h might have produced 7,410–10,260 features. At the highest rate, desktop GIS digitisation using novice volunteers is almost competitive with the mobile application approach we used.

evidence.evidence_text: 57h of staff time produced 10,827 features via crowdsourcing = 190 features per staff-hour
evidence.verbatim_quote: By comparison, the 57 h of staff time required for our digitisation approach using a customisation of FAIMS Mobile produced 10,827 features, or about 190 features per staff-hour.

evidence.evidence_text: Urban Occupations Project: 1,250h manual digitisation for training data + 7 days ML expert fine-tuning = minimum 1,300h total for ML approach that digitised 300,000 km of roads
evidence.verbatim_quote: The ERC-funded Urban Occupations Project (Can, Gerrits, and Kabadayi 2021), however, provides one benchmark for judging when pursuing a ML approach might be worthwhile. This project reported 1,250 h of manual digitisation to create enough training data to classify roads visible in historical maps of the Ottoman Empire. Using this input, and after additional preprocessing and filtering, an ML expert spent seven days testing and fine tuning the model. The output was impressive: some 300,000 km of roads were digitised. This example, which appears to have required a minimum of about 1,300 h of preparation time alone, suggests that ML approaches are worthwhile for large-scale projects that benefit from the consistent symbology and style (as found in British and Ottoman imperial maps).

claims.claim_text: The crowdsourcing approach using FAIMS Mobile successfully produced a large dataset (10,827 features) with reasonable effort investment
claims.verbatim_quote: Deployed in Bulgaria as an ancillary activity during 2017–2018 archaeological fieldwork, FAIMS Mobile was used to digitise 10,827 mound features from Soviet military topographic maps. This digitisation required 241 person-hours (57 from staff; 184 from novice volunteers), with an error rate under 6%.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Abstract and Conclusion made identical core claim. Consolidated to eliminate redundancy.

claims.claim_text: The resulting dataset from crowdsourced digitisation was consistent, well-documented, high-quality, and analysis-ready
claims.verbatim_quote: The resulting dataset was consistent, well-documented, and ready for analysis with a few hours of processing.

claims.claim_text: Conservative estimate suggests crowdsourcing approach is most efficient for digitisation projects of 10,000–60,000 features, but may offer advantages for datasets as small as a few hundred records
claims.verbatim_quote: A conservative estimate based on our work suggests our crowdsourcing approach is most efficient for digitisation projects of 10,000–60,000 features, but may offer advantages for datasets as small as a few hundred records.

claims.claim_text: Systems designed for field data collection, running on mobile devices, can be profitably customised to serve as participatory geospatial data systems accessible to novice volunteers
claims.verbatim_quote: Furthermore, it indicates that systems designed for field data collection, running on mobile devices, can be profitably customised to serve as participatory geospatial data systems accessible to novice volunteers.

claims.claim_text: Unlocking data from historical maps for landscape analysis is costly
claims.verbatim_quote: Unlocking data from historical maps for landscape analysis is costly.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS Mobile platform was tailored to offer a streamlined, collaborative system for crowdsourcing map digitisation by volunteers with no prior GIS experience
claims.verbatim_quote: Here we present a customisation of the Field Acquired Information Management Systems (FAIMS) Mobile platform tailored to offer a streamlined, collaborative system for crowdsourcing map digitisation by volunteers with no prior GIS experience.

claims.claim_text: Existing research provides little guidance as to when investments in different digitisation approaches become worthwhile
claims.verbatim_quote: Existing research provides little guidance as to when investments in these approaches become worthwhile.

claims.claim_text: Burial mounds are an irreplaceable but endangered aspect of Bulgarian cultural heritage, making systematic recording urgent for research and heritage management
claims.verbatim_quote: Burial mounds are an irreplaceable - but endangered - aspect of Bulgarian cultural heritage, making their systematic recording and registration an urgent undertaking for both research and cultural heritage management.

claims.claim_text: The ability to record mounds that no longer exist but are represented in historical maps is especially important as evidence of past landscapes and to assess ongoing damage
claims.verbatim_quote: The ability to record mounds that no longer exist, but are represented in historical maps, is especially important as evidence of past landscapes and to assess ongoing damage to mounds.

claims.claim_text: Manual digitisation using desktop GIS is time-consuming and requires specialised skills
claims.verbatim_quote: Manually drawing and annotating shapes in historical maps using a desktop GIS is time-consuming and requires specialised skills (Can, Gerrits, and Kabadayi 2021; Petrie et al., 2018; Jones & Weber, 2012).

claims.claim_text: Desktop GIS principal limitations are difficulty of scaling the effort, particularly restricted time and availability of expert users
claims.verbatim_quote: Its principal limitations are difficulty of scaling the effort, particularly restricted time and availability of expert users to either undertake digitisation themselves, or to train and support novices to the extent required for efficient and accurate work (see also Jessop, 2007 for other challenges).

claims.claim_text: ML has unmatched potential for large-scale data digitisation
claims.verbatim_quote: ML has unmatched potential for large-scale data digitisation, but it requires specific programming expertise, and familiarity with the capabilities and limitations of ML.

claims.claim_text: ML requires specific expertise (programming, ML capabilities/limitations), has risk of bias, and requires manual training data preparation that may be difficult for smaller HASS projects
claims.verbatim_quote: ML has unmatched potential for large-scale data digitisation, but it requires specific programming expertise, and familiarity with the capabilities and limitations of ML. Naive use of ML is likely to produce biased or otherwise unreliable results (Mehrabi et al., 2021; Schwemmer et al., 2020; Besse et al., 2018; Fuchs, 2018; Haas, 2017), even if pretrained image recognition models are used (Jiang et al., 2022).

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing offers advantages compared to alternative approaches under many map digitisation scenarios
claims.verbatim_quote: This paper argues that crowdsourcing offers advantages compared to alternative approaches under many, if not most, map digitisation scenarios.

claims.claim_text: Volunteers often lack the skills necessary to use GIS software, with experience limited to simple web mapping
claims.verbatim_quote: Volunteers often lack the skills necessary to use GIS software (Elwood, 2008b; Jones & Weber, 2012; Owen et al., 2009). Often, their experience is limited to 'dropping pins' on web 'slippy-maps' like Google Maps.

claims.claim_text: Expert training approach to bridge digital divide scales poorly due to restricted expert time and volunteer willingness limits
claims.verbatim_quote: This 'digital divide' can be bridged in part through more expert training and guidance of novice users (Owen et al., 2009, p. 24). Such an approach scales poorly, however; the supply of expert time available to any project is restricted and often oversubscribed, while the willingness of volunteers to learn specialised skills and software has limits.

claims.claim_text: Expert interaction can be profitably supplemented by development of 'useful' tools that combine utility with usability
claims.verbatim_quote: While some expert interaction is unavoidable and desirable, it can be profitably supplemented by the development of 'useful' tools that combine 'utility' with 'usability' (Nielsen, 2012).

claims.claim_text: Mobile applications may be particularly suited to production of Volunteered Geographic Information (VGI)
claims.verbatim_quote: Mobile applications may be particularly suited to the production of Volunteered Geographic Information (VGI).

claims.claim_text: The minimally resourced digitisation effort was unexpectedly successful
claims.verbatim_quote: The value of this approach lies in the unanticipated success of a minimally resourced digitisation effort, as well as the resulting dataset's value for archaeological research and cultural heritage management.

claims.claim_text: Compared to manual digitisation using desktop GIS, the approach required little training/supervision, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced large accurate analysis-ready dataset
claims.verbatim_quote: Compared to manual digitisation approaches based on desktop GIS, it required little training or supervision of students, used open-source software and low-cost equipment, yet produced a large, accurate, analysis-ready dataset.

claims.claim_text: The approach complements ML in requiring less technical expertise, time, and resourcing
claims.verbatim_quote: It complements Machine Learning (ML) and other automated approaches in that it requires less technical expertise, time, and resourcing to undertake.

claims.claim_text: The approach is suitable for projects with small to mid-sized data sources (100s-10,000s of features) that don't warrant ML investment, and for exploratory work or training data production
claims.verbatim_quote: Such an approach is suitable for projects working with small to mid-sized data sources (100s–10,000s of features) that do not warrant the investment needed for successful ML-based data extraction - as well as for exploratory work preceding automated analyses or the production of the training and quality assurance datasets needed for ML.

claims.claim_text: The approach focused on implementing tools to empower volunteers to digitise independently with minimal training and supervision
claims.verbatim_quote: In 2017, faced with a short field season and little time for student training, we focused on implementing tools that would empower volunteers to digitise maps independently. Our approach sought to help novice users begin digitising quickly and then work productively for the duration of each field season with minimal support or frustration.

claims.claim_text: Decision to use mobile software and FAIMS Mobile was based on: offline capability, functional requirements for geospatial software, testing usability approaches from fieldwork, platform reuse, student touch-screen preference, reduced hardware/licensing competition, and open-source transparency
claims.verbatim_quote: The decision to use mobile software, and FAIMS Mobile in particular, was based on several factors.

claims.claim_text: Customised mobile application met fundamental usability requirements, resulting in simple familiar interface enabling novices to begin with little training, resume after hiatus, with low attrition
claims.verbatim_quote: By contrast, our customised application met fundamental usability requirements (e.g., Nielsen, 2012), both due to careful design of the customisation itself, and the underlying platform's implementation of Google's Material Design guidelines. It also benefited from the UI/UX approach employed for kinetic fieldwork (e.g., Pascoe et al., 2000). The principle that the technology had to conform to the workflow, rather than vice versa, translated particularly well to map digitisation. The result was a simple, familiar mobile application interface that let novices begin work with little training and helped them resume work after any hiatus. Use of controlled vocabularies, automation, and validation reduced errors. Low volunteer attrition indicated satisfaction with the experience.

claims.claim_text: Overall accuracy was high, over 94% for processed maps
claims.verbatim_quote: Unlike some volunteer digitisation projects, overall accuracy was high, over 94% for processed maps.

claims.claim_text: Crowdsourcing approach using FAIMS Mobile is most suitable for datasets of 10,000-60,000 records based on comparative calculations with desktop GIS approaches
claims.verbatim_quote: To summarise in round numbers, a crowdsourcing approach like ours is most suitable for datasets numbering perhaps 10,000–60,000 records, assuming similar feature characteristics and data collection requirements (see Table 5). Below 10,000 records, approaches using desktop GIS should be considered. Under the most conservative scenario that considers all invested time, the use of our system pays off between about 3,500–4,500 features versus direct digitisation by staff using desktop GIS, and about 7,500–10,000 features versus support for volunteers using desktop GIS.

claims.claim_text: Above 60,000 records ML approaches should be contemplated, but only if project has access to requisite expertise
claims.verbatim_quote: Above 60,000 records, ML approaches should be contemplated, but only if a project has access to the requisite expertise.

claims.claim_text: ML and crowdsourcing approaches are not exclusive but complementary - training datasets big enough to justify ML may warrant crowdsourcing, and crowdsourcing platforms can produce error-checking datasets for ML
claims.verbatim_quote: Finally, since training a model requires a manually produced dataset and a degree of manual error-checking, a combination of ML and crowdsourcing approaches might serve even large-scale projects. A dataset big enough to justify ML will likely need a training dataset big enough to warrant crowdsourcing, especially if the features or background are variable. Once the crowdsourcing platform has been built, moreover, it can be used to produce additional datasets for error-checking to confirm the accuracy of the ML results. The approaches are not exclusive, therefore, but complementary.

claims.claim_text: A typical HASS project may not be able to dedicate personnel/infrastructure/attention needed for ML successfully, but could deploy collaborative geospatial system for crowdsourcing
claims.verbatim_quote: Today, a typical project in history or archaeology - often small, under-resourced, and pursuing several research activities - may not be able to dedicate the personnel, infrastructure, or attention needed to incorporate ML successfully, but could deploy a collaborative geospatial system for crowdsourcing map digitisation.

claims.claim_text: The approach is readily transferable to other mobile GIS systems and map corpora
claims.verbatim_quote: This approach is readily transferable to other mobile GIS systems and map corpora, but our experience provides only a single data point for assessing the applicability of various digitisation approaches to historical maps.

research_designs.design_text: Case study of crowdsourced map digitization using novice volunteers with mobile GIS during archaeological fieldwork
research_designs.verbatim_quote: This article presents a case study of crowdsourced cultural heritage digitisation from historical maps undertaken by volunteers using a lightweight, streamlined Geographical Information System (GIS) running offline on mobile devices. The value of this approach lies in the unanticipated success of a minimally resourced digitisation effort, as well as the resulting dataset's value for archaeological research and cultural heritage management. Digitisation was undertaken as a secondary activity on a landscape archaeology project focusing on pedestrian feature survey. Undergraduates in the associated field school digitised data from maps using a system repurposed from other project activities.

methods.method_text: Crowdsourcing approach using mobile GIS platform (FAIMS Mobile) customized for map digitization by novice volunteers
methods.verbatim_quote: For the 2017–2018 field seasons, TRAP staff created a simplified and streamlined data capture system built using the FAIMS Mobile platform. This system allowed any number of participants to digitise map features using mobile devices, regardless of network connectivity, and consolidated the resulting data when a network became available.
methods.data_collection_approach: Volunteer digitization of georeferenced historical maps using customized mobile application
expected_information_missing: Volunteer recruitment criteria beyond 'field school participants'
Quality control procedures during digitization (documented after the fact in section 2.5)

methods.method_text: Platform selection: FAIMS Mobile chosen over desktop GIS and competing mobile platforms based on offline capability, functional requirements, usability transferability, platform reuse, student interface preferences, hardware/licensing constraints, and open-source transparency
methods.verbatim_quote: The decision to use mobile software, and FAIMS Mobile in particular, was based on several factors. First, FAIMS Mobile worked offline. Our digitisation took place alongside fieldwork, at field bases in rural Bulgaria. Reliable internet connectivity could not be guaranteed under these circumstances; a system that tolerated degraded network connectivity was required. In our experience, digitisation work associated with archaeological research often proceeds under such conditions. Second, this system met the functional requirements we identified for geospatial software.
methods.alternative_methods_considered: Desktop GIS (ArcGIS), ESRI ArcGIS Collector, ESRI Survey123
methods.selection_rationale: Offline operation, functional requirements met, usability approach transferability from fieldwork, platform reuse, student touch-screen preference, reduced hardware/licensing competition, open-source transparency

methods.method_text: Participant recruitment: Undergraduate field school students from range of Arts/Humanities backgrounds, most with no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods
methods.verbatim_quote: Our students came from a range of academic backgrounds in Arts and Humanities. Most had no training in archaeology, cartography, or digital methods (unlike Pődör, 2015 or Can et al., 2021).

sampling_strategy.sampling_rationale: Field school participants already present for archaeological survey
sampling_strategy.planned_coverage: All willing field school participants across 2017-2018 seasons

Participation rate (how many students participated vs total enrolled)

methods.method_text: Comparative evaluation approach: cataloguing inputs (staff/volunteer time) versus outputs (features digitized), then calculating payoff thresholds by comparing person-hours invested to features produced under different approaches (expert GIS, volunteer GIS, crowdsourcing, ML)
methods.verbatim_quote: At that point, we decided to catalogue inputs (time invested by staff and volunteers) versus outputs (features digitised) as part of a research program to evaluate digital approaches to fieldwork (e.g., Sobotkova et al., 2016). To measure inputs, we collated the amount of time spent by various participants in the process, including the student programmer who instantiated the customisation, the student volunteers who undertook the digitisation, and project staff who configured the system, supported volunteers, exported data, and checked for errors.
methods.analysis_approach: Time-motion study comparing person-hours invested to features produced; comparative threshold analysis extrapolating from empirical data to estimate break-even points for different approaches
expected_information_missing: Statistical analysis methods for comparing approaches

methods.method_text: Feature selection strategy: extracting symbols from 1:50,000 Soviet topographic maps that might represent burial or settlement mounds
methods.verbatim_quote: The goal of the work was to extract archaeological features from 1:50,000 scale Soviet military topographic maps dating to the 1980s. Available as georeferenced GeoTIFFs (from http://web.uni-plovdiv.bg/vedrin/index_en.html in 2008), each of these maps covers ca 400 sq km. We wished to extract symbols from them that might represent burial or settlement mounds in our study area (see Fig. 2).

protocols.protocol_text: FAIMS Mobile customization: simplified interface focusing on layer selection, shape digitization, and annotation, with streamlined map/form view toggle, automated capabilities (SRS application, map rendering, layer management, topology enforcement, controlled vocabularies, metadata capture, validation, multi-device merging, data export), and focused UI design for novice users
protocols.verbatim_quote: Our approach sought to help novice users begin digitising quickly and then work productively for the duration of each field season with minimal support or frustration. protocols.protocol_text: System customization workflow: (1) staff data/workflow modeling, (2) programmer customization (35h 2017, 1h 2018), (3) staff spatial reference and map preprocessing, (4) volunteer shape digitization, (5) volunteer attribute transcription, (6) staff data export, (7) staff accuracy checking
protocols.verbatim_quote: The stages of FAIMS Mobile implementation (Fig. 3) included: (1) project staff modelled the data and workflow to ensure that the final dataset met research needs, (2) a junior software developer worked with project staff to customise the system, (3) project staff defined a spatial reference system (SRS) and imported preprocessed historical maps, (4) volunteers drew a shape (usually a point) wherever they saw a target symbol and (5) volunteers transcribed attributes from the map, (6) project staff exported data using the FAIMS Mobile server, (7) project staff undertook a targeted accuracy-checking exercise.
